lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen and identify key details about Ruma's school by choosing correct answers (e.g., matching sentence halves).
supportStrategies: (Listening) Play part of the video. Pause and ask: “What does Ruma have?” Students point to matching pictures in their books.
stretchStrategies: Turn the video review into a “Freeze and Speak” game. Play the video and freeze it at any scene. Students describe what’s happening: “The boy is sitting.” “She’s opening her book.” Add thinking questions: “Is she happy or sad?” “What will happen next?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can identify one thing Ruma likes about school and explain if they feel the same or different.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Draw a Venn diagram on the board: “Ruma’s school / My school.” Students suggest similarities and differences.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can talk about why school is important and name one reason some children can’t go every day.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Ask: “Why do some children not go to school?” Write ideas on the board. Prompt with visuals if needed.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
